pullRequest.body:
The category of finite topological spaces.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->
This is needed to obtain the category of finite continuous `G`-types for a topological group `G`. This would then be
`ContAction FinTopCat G`.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Is there a reason not to use `Finite Î±` instead of `Fintype`?
Yes, because `FintypeCat` uses `Fintype`, so to have a computable forgetful functor to `FintypeCat`, this is needed and also for consistency reasons I think it makes sense that way.

You can still define that functor -- you can always get a `Fintype`Â instance from a `Finite`Â instance (`Fintype.ofFinite`) -- it's just that `Finite`Â is a `Prop`Â and `Fintype`Â contains data. You can read the docstring [here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Finite/Defs.html#Finite) for an explanation on when to use `Finite`Â and when to use `Fintype`

I agree, but that's what would make the forgetful functor `noncomputable`. And, as I said, for consistency I think it makes sense to have the same typeclass assumption as in `FintypeCat`.

If I am understanding correctly, if I start with an object `X` of `FintypeCat` with a topological space instance and write `(forgetâ‚‚ FinTopCat FintypeCat).obj (FinTopCat.of X)`, with the `Finite` approach I would get two (possibly non def-eq) `Fintype` instances on `X` (the one I started with and the one from `Fintype.ofFinite`).

Do you care about data that tells you in what way your spaces are finite? If not, I think you should use `Finite`, because there is no way to get two different `Finite`Â instances.

I think there are lots of uses of `Fintype` in the library that could be changed to `Finite`.

But let's get an opinion from a different reviewer.

Note that I don't care about the `Fintype` instance, I just think that `FintypeCat` and `FinTopCat` should use the same notion of finiteness.

And I agree with you, I am in favor of using `Finite` instead of `Fintype`.

I agree that `FinTopCat` and `FintypeCat` should have the same finiteness. Someone might want to open a Zulip discussion on whether `FintypeCat` should be changed to `FiniteCat` in case `FintypeCat` has some combinatorial applications that needs the `Fintype` instance.
I agree that unless the name/definition of `FintypeCat` is changed, it is very much ok to keep the `Fintype` assumption here.

You probably want to use `C(X, Y)` instead. An even simpler solution would be to use `InducedCategory.category` to inherit the category instance from `TopCat`, but then you need to change the definition of `FinTopCat`Â so that one of the fields is an object of `TopCat`. This gives you lots of the stuff below for free, you can compare with the definitions of `CompHaus`Â and `Profinite`Â for example.
Should the spelling be `(forget _).obj X` or `X` (from the `CoeSort` instance)?
If this does not break things, I would favour the `CoeSort` versoin.

The `CoeSort` version already works:
```
example (X : FinTopCat) : Fintype X := inferInstance
```
but
```
example (X : FinTopCat) : Fintype ((forget FinTopCat).obj X) := inferInstance
```
does not without the instance above and I think I'll need this one.
It's sad that we need that. I really hope we can sort out the coercions of concrete categories one day.
Should I do anything about this in this case or can we merge this PR then?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Topology/Category): category of finite topological spaces
